edges.to_node_long: G1 Changes in landscape and waterscape character
edges.rationale: Changes in environmental outcomes from our Designated Landscapes will be considered as part of the G1 indicator.
edges.from_node_long: D2 Extent and condition of protected sites – land, water and sea

edges.to_node_long: D1 Quantity, quality and connectivity of habitats
edges.rationale: Accessible natural greenspaces have an important contribution to make to the quality of the environment in urban areas. Such sites provide important refuges for wildlife in otherwise impoverished areas.
edges.from_node_long: G3 Enhancement of green/blue infrastructure

edges.rationale: Green and blue spaces and features in and around our built environment, including within Green Belts, are essential to health and well-being.
edges.from_node_long: G3 Enhancement of green/blue infrastructure

edges.rationale: G7 shows that most people agree that spending time outdoors is important for their physical and mental health.
edges.from_node_long: G4 Engagement in the natural environment

edges.to_node_long: D2 Extent and condition of protected sites – land, water and sea
edges.rationale: G5 includes data on volunteer hours from organisations that manage protected areas such as the Wildlife Trusts.

edges.rationale: G6 will include information on people’s self-reported environmental behaviours, likely including questions on water use.

edges.rationale: G6 will include information on people’s self-reported environmental behaviours, likely including questions on waste.

edges.rationale: G6 will include information on people’s self-reported environmental behaviours, likely including questions on behaviours related to carbon use.

edges.rationale: Long-term exposure to particulate matter contributes to the risk of developing cardiovascular disease and lung cancer.
edges.from_node_long: A3 Concentrations of fine particulate matter (PM2.5) in the air

edges.rationale: Ozone is a gas which is damaging to human health and can trigger inflammation of the respiratory tract, eyes, nose and throat as well as asthma attacks.
edges.from_node_long: A4 Rural background concentrations of ozone (O3)

edges.rationale: Short-term exposure to concentrations of NO2 can cause inflammation of the airways and increase susceptibility to respiratory infections and to allergens. NO2 can exacerbate the symptoms of those already suffering from lung or heart conditions.
edges.from_node_long: A5 Roadside nitrogen dioxide (NO2) concentrations

edges.to_node_long: G1 Changes in landscape and waterscape character
edges.rationale: Nutrient nitrogen deposition affects the nutrient levels and diversity of species in sensitive environments, for example, by encouraging algae growth in lakes and water courses.
edges.from_node_long: A6 Exceedance of damaging levels of nutrient nitrogen deposition on ecosystems

edges.rationale: The 2 higher categories of serious pollution event cause, for example, potential harm to bathers.
edges.from_node_long: B2 Serious pollution incidents to water

edges.rationale: Status of bathing waters is based on a set of microbiological tests (measuring E.coli and intestinal enterococci) performed on waters used for bathing. The bacteria, if present, can cause severe stomach upsets and gastro-intestinal illness.
edges.from_node_long: B4 Condition of bathing waters

edges.to_node_long: G1 Changes in landscape and waterscape character
edges.rationale: G1 will consider attributes of landscape such as woodland cover.
edges.from_node_long: D3 Area of woodland in England

edges.rationale: Woodland will be included in metrics of green infrastructure.
edges.from_node_long: D3 Area of woodland in England

edges.to_node_long: G4 Engagement in the natural environment
edges.rationale: Some visits to the natural environment will be visits to woodland.
edges.from_node_long: D3 Area of woodland in England

edges.rationale: POPs are chemicals that remain intact in the environment for long periods, become widely distributed geographically, accumulate in the tissues of humans and wildlife, and have harmful impacts on human health or on the environment. Mercury is toxic and can cause damage to human health and accumulates in the environment and the food chain.
edges.from_node_long: H3 Emissions of mercury and persistent organic pollutants to the environment

edges.rationale: Health costs (and hence burden to the economy) of noise can be estimated from health outcomes associated with noise exposure (such as annoyance, sleep disturbance, and cardiovascular effects).
edges.from_node_long: H5 Exposure to transport noise

edges.rationale: Chemicals measured in J5 include POPs which can bioaccumulate and have harmful impacts on health.
edges.from_node_long: J5 Prevent harmful chemicals from being recycled

edges.to_node_long: G1 Changes in landscape and waterscape character
edges.rationale: Fly tipping will influence changes in the public’s perceptions of landscape character and quality, which will become part of the G1 indicator.
edges.from_node_long: J6 Waste crime
